results.title: Money movement mindst
results.brief_description: Annoying finance bros beware: the comedians are coming for your grindset! Financial planning is a popular podcast and video genre online — but many of them are hosted by young men whose views on how to make bank can be hilariously macho, and based on an unrealistic picture of how and why most people spend their money. In this video, Tiktok comedian Caroline Baniewicz skewers finance bro culture, satirising the impractical ways that these podcasters advise on making your first million.

results.title: Michelle Yeoh wins Best Actress at Oscars 2023: ‘Beacon of hope’
results.credit_line: Recorded from New York Post’s Youtube Chanel
results.material_description: Screen recording from New York Post's YouTube channel
results.brief_description: Michelle Yeoh described her win for Best Actress as a beacon of hope for Asian audiences everywhere. In an Oscar’s first, Yeoh became the first Asian woman to win the award in its history, only the second woman of color to take home that award ever. Halle Berry, the first WOC to win in the same category over 20 years ago, presented the award
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Michelle Yeoh described her win for Best Actress as a beacon of hope for Asian audiences everywhere. In an Oscar’s first, Yeoh became the first Asian woman to win the award in its history, only the second woman of color to take home that award ever. Halle Berry, the first WOC to win in the same category over 20 years ago, presented the award.

results.title: Melbourne: festival city
results.creator_credit: Gordon C. Lloyd, Tourist Development Authority of Victoria and Cinesound
results.brief_description: Melbourne’s Moomba festival - the city comes alive with processions, regattas, the Herald open air art show, music under the stars at the Myer Music Bowl, and the crowning of the Moomba Queen. The film also shows some of the Melbourne landscape and the background of daily life; Melbourne’s economic expansion; the Melbourne Cup, the race for which the nation stands still; Australian Rules Football, drawing crowds of over 50,000; fine golf courses; hunting; night life. It closes with a coverage of the Moomba procession, with all its varied floats, including the Bunyip and the Chinese dragon.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gordon C. Lloyd, Tourist Development Authority of Victoria and Cinesound

results.title: Wall to wall in wool
results.brief_description: Design and manufacture of carpets in an Australian factory.
results.description: Design and manufacture of carpets in an Australian factory.

Agriculture, Business, Commerce & Industry → Wool industry - Australia

group_siblings.title: Melbourne: festival city
group_siblings.creator_credit: Gordon C. Lloyd, Tourist Development Authority of Victoria and Cinesound

results.title: [Release prints compilation]
results.brief_description:
1. Wall to Wall Wool - Documents the process of wool carpet production from design illustrations of a bunch of flowers to the manufacture of finished carpet with similar design. Primarily focuses on the many types of machinery used to create the carpet. Contains nice images of a carpet-making factory, specifically the colourful flower-patterned carpet juxtaposed within an industrial backdrop. Good ‘The End’. (12m 44sec)

  2. Melbourne: Festival City - Made by the Victorian Tourist Development Authority in the 1960s. Essentially an ad for Melbourne, focusing on the ‘highly popular’ Moomba Festival. Great images of large crowds watching the Moomba parade as well as having fun on rides, watching watersports and eating/drinking (including Latte drinkers). Also shows the ‘recently completed’ Sydney Myer Music Bowl, footage of a game of football at the MCG and highlights Melbourne as the ‘Fashion Capital’. Nice closing shot of the city, focusing on St. Pauls and a Fed Square-less Flinders St, as well as the Yarra. Good titles and ‘The End’. (10 mins)

  3. Hydatids - Australian Wool Bureau production. Highlights the dangers of Hydatid disease and the ease of which it can be both contracted and negated. This includes washing hands after having contact with dogs and boiling all sheep offal before feeding it to dogs. Contains footage of a farmer gutting a sheep and cute diagrams of how the hydatids disease can spread from sheep to dogs to humans. (10 mins)

results.title: K-Rad Man
results.brief_description: A Mad Scientist creates the ultimate computer virus and locates a suitable test subject: K-Rad Man - to whom he can expose the computer virus and gauge its results.

results.title: Drat
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Robert Stephenson, Ann Shenfield, Sarah Watt and Elizabeth O'Neill
results.brief_description: A bunch of lab rats one night decide to break out and escape from their cages in the laboratory. One brain damaged rat, as a result of receiving shock-treatment, initially resists the call. This claymation reveals in its close yet another fiendish experiment.

results.title: Paddington in the hot seat. Paddington's puzzle. Paddington takes a cut.
results.creator_credit: Barry Leith, Ivor Wood, Graham Clutterbuck, FilmFair Communications and Paddington
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The wonderful world of Paddington Bear”.
1. “Paddington in the hot seat”. Paddington has an audience ticket for the Quiz Show “Sage of Britain”. He gets lost in the studio complex and finds himself “on camera” where he is interviewed by Lionel Parr. He disputes the scoring and provides his opinion on proposed changes to British Television. The viewers jam the switchboard and Paddington is announced “Sage of Britain”. - 2. “Paddington’s puzzle”. Paddington makes a jigsaw puzzle as a present for Mr Gruber from a “priceless” old painting discarded by Mr Curry, some plywood and glue. - 3. “Paddington takes a cut”. Paddington reads “Clippings from my Hedgerow” and dreams he is pruning Mr Currys’ shrub into a peacock shape. Disaster strikes when he snips it leg off! However, awakes before discovery by Mr Curry!
results.title_for_label: Paddington in the hot seat. Paddington’s puzzle. Paddington takes a cut.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barry Leith, Ivor Wood, Graham Clutterbuck, FilmFair Communications and Paddington

results.title: High hopes
results.creator_credit: Mike Leigh, Simon Channing-Williams and Portman Film
results.brief_description: Winner of the International Critics Award, Mike Leigh’s tragi-comedy depicts Great Britain as a divided serfdom. One half of the population is in thrall to Dayglo dreams of social ascent, the other half to dissent and wistful radicalism. In converted slum-lands, yuppies live side by side with the last surviving council tenants, and in stubborn bedsits, the last surviving Marxists hold out, growing unwashed beards with the devotion of scientists. The film’s triumph is the depiction, at once satirical and compassionate, of its two aging Marxists, two lost souls like you and me, who soldier on with their small lives while the large world outside moves inevitably towards eternity or Armageddon.

results.title: Asterix the Gaul
results.brief_description: Asterix, the adventurous hero is the cunning little warrior to whom all perilous missions are immediately entrusted. Thanks to the magic potion of the Druid, he is famed for his superhuman strength. As if that were not enough, his mighty friend, Obelix is always ready to drop everything to go off on a new adventure with Asterix, although he is never allowed to have a portion of the magic potion because he fell into it when he was a baby. Wherever excitement and danger reigns, you can be sure that our intrepid pair will be in the thick of it. So Romans beware, here comes Asterix the Gaul. Based on the popular books by Goscinny and Underzo.
